Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Uncertainty reduction through better nonlinear particle filters
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to create and implement new methods for improving the performance of filtering, or data assimilation techniques, applied to non-linear, non-Gaussian systems. Many problems in computational statistics, artificial intelligence, and geophysics involve such systems, and utilize specialized Monte Carlo sampling methods, called particle filters, for data analysis and forecasting, and for better understanding of the underlying phenomena. The principal investigator studies variational data assimilation methods to demonstrate that targeted ensemble generation using those methods delivers more effective filter performance, and that dynamic adaptation of the size of the particle ensemble improves the computational efficiency of the filter.

Statistical computations are an essential tool for the solution of problems in such diverse areas as artificial intelligence, industrial and consumer electronics, robotics, weather systems, climate change, ocean ecosystems, and land surface processes. The proposed research improves statistical computations required for the analysis, estimation, and forecasting of information that arrives over time, and contributes to a better combination of theoretical models with observational data. In addition, the project involves the training of undergraduate students in applied scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to better understand natural phenomena, scientists build mathematical models to reproduce them. Furthermore, well-built models can be used to forecast future events. These models are frequently used in weather forecasting, climate prediction, fluid dynamics, and land surface processes as well as artificial intelligence applications such as image processing, speech recognition and robot navigations. Often times, the forecasted quantity deviates from the truth due to various factors including human incomplete understanding of the nature as well as numerical computing errors. One major goal in scientific forecasting is to reduce forecast errors. Forecasts are made for future times; however, when the future becomes current with time passes by, measurement for the actual forecasted quantity can be obtained. The difference between the forecasted and the actual quantity reveals the errors in the model. This research project explores the process: data assimilation, which optimally combines the forecasted and the measured quantity to improve the model forecast, making models more accurate and run faster.

In classic data assimilation algorithms, the assimilation happens periodically whenever the measurement data becomes available. This project proposed two new methods to make the assimilation process run faster with more accurate results. The first is to dynamically adjust the number of simultaneous model runs; the second is to adjust how frequently the assimilation should be performed. Both methods were tested on complex forecast simulation models. The numerical analysis results show improved performance compared to the classic data assimilation methods. These promising results opened the door to further customize the data assimilation algorithm based on specific application.  It also motivated future research of close integration of physical models and data models.

Through this project, six undergraduate students at a small liberal arts college were supported and trained to carry out scientific research including literature reading, algorithm design, implementation with computer programming, numerical analysis, paper writing, poster making and presenting at professional conferences. These experiences have greatly motivated them to future engage in scientific research. The project also created research experience for women undergraduate students.
